messages: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:18): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: OK, please try again when you have time
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:18): on http://qa-dev.w3.org:8888/
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:18): I don't actually know how to run your test case myself
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:19): because I don't know how to make v.nu use data: URIs
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (10:19): curses people with loud car/door/something alarms
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (10:20): and especially those that let them go off so many times people can no longer sleep
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:21): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: I get an error on the console, "unsupported protocol: 'data'"
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:24): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: i just copied the text into the textarea
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:27): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: i still get the relaxng error for <input usemap>
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:28): shit
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:28): lemme check
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:29): ah yeah

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:30): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: maybe the messages should say "The foo attribute on element bar is obsolete" instead of just "The foo attribute is obsolete" since e.g. <link target> is obsolete but <a target> isn't
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (10:30): finds a page which behaves differently with %26 and & in the URI
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:30): there's not a single attribute pattern for the input element in the scheme
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:30): *schema
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:31): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: yeah, I guess we should have it do that
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:31): the schema adds attributes depending on what type is, doesn't it?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:31): for input
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:31): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:32): so that means I have to add it to 20 different patterns
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:32): isn't there input.attrs.common or so?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:32): maybe
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:32): I can't remember.. I'll look
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:33): i guess usemap was only valid for type=image anyway
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:33): so you could just add it to type=image and leave the rest
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:34): yeah, true
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:35): s/valid/used/

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:35): anyway, fwiw, there is no input.attrs.common pattern (or equivalent) -- I guess because there are no attributes common to all input elements that aren't also common too all form attributes (or that aren't global on all elements)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:36): isn't "type" common to all form elements?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:36): er, to all inputs I mean, but not other form elements?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:37): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: yes, but since the schema has different patterns depending on type, that's not particularly helpful in this case
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (10:37): depends, all form elements do have a type IDL attribute
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:37): has no idea what the context is, just sayin'
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:40): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: also <object code>
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:41): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: that one I omitted intentionally.. because afaict no published spec ever allowed code on object anyway
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:41): do people actually use code on object?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:41): I thought it was just for applet
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:41): I wasn't sure if it was included in the list intentionally or not
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:41): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: dunno, maybe the spec is wrong in listing <object code> as obsolete
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:42): same for <param type>?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:43): checks on <param type>
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:44): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: also align on input
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:44): ah yeah
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:44): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: gives 2 messages
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:45): that I will need to add to a lot more patterns
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:46): hsivonen: I wouldn't expect the DOM to depend on network packet boundaries
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:46): hmm, html4 doesn't have <input align>
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:47): oh but html 3.2 does
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:49): wonders if we have reached any conclusion about coalescing text nodes in general

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:49): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: maybe the message for <img border=1> and <script language=vbscript> should advice to use the preferred alternative instead of advicing to alter the value
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:51): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: the warnings for those cases basically come directly from what's mandated in the spec
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:51): I think
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:51): it looks like html4 loose allowed <param type>
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:51): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: yes, but if you have <script language=vbscript>, you don't want to change that to <script language=javascript>

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:52): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: because presumably the script was vbscript and language is still obsolete so changing the value still won't silence the validator
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:52): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: it should advice to use <script type=text/vbscript>
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:52): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: right, I see what you're saying now
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:52): please file a bug on that one if you have time
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (10:57): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: no message for <ul><li type> and <ol type> and <ul type>
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:01): hmm, that one's weird
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:05): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: no clue on that one yet.. code seems right
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:06): but I'll check in the other changes shortly
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:06): ah, found it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:07): (dumb mistake)
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (11:25): http://www.w3.org/mid/<email/> is somewhat interesting
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (11:25): browser vendors abused the SVG WG
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (11:25): heard it here first
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:34): cause we're mean
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:35): the SVG WG was guilty of self-abuse
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:53): Opera supports the uDOM?
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (11:54): unfortunately yes
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (11:54): hopefully nobody else adds it
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:55): seems like it is on the active disinterest list for WebKit and Gecko at least
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:57): SVG Tiny 1.2 is a REC? now that's an implementation report I gotta read
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (11:58): not sure how that worked either; hopefully now more browsers are involved the next SVG will be better
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (11:58): "The only way to have features put into SVG or any other W3C
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (11:58): spec is to participate in the group, attend teleconferences,
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (11:58): face to face meetings and back your cause."
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:59): hmm the implementation report doesn't seem to include even a single implementation passing all the tests
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:00): their "two implementations" requirement is per test
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (12:01): so i can write an implementation that passes one test, and it would count?
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (12:03): you'd need another
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:03): Allowing partial implementations as evidence that the spec as a whole is implementable seems like it has obvious flaws
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (12:04): i guess in the trade-off perfection vs moving forward they picked moving forward
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:04): "The CR exit criteria were a minimum of two implementations passing each test in the test suite, of which at least one must be running on a mobile platform."
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (12:04): writes an impl that does nothing but showing "PASS", which magically passes lots of tests
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:05): that first clause is ambiguous

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:08): I don't see why they tested Firefox or Safari (they only "passed" two tests total) but it looks like they needed all of the other 8 implementations tested to meet their CR exit criteria
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:11): interesting to see Microsoft following SVG

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:13): wonders if anyone has worked out the historical correlation between Microsoft commenting on details of specs and them implementing it in the next version of IE
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:16): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: I checked in several changes and I think fixed the misses you've reported so far
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:17): except for object/@code, which I'm still not sure whether that's in the list intentionally or inadvertently
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (12:18): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: file a spec bug on object code
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:18): I'm looking for MAMA on that one too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:20): no @code in http://dev.opera.com/articles/view/mama-plug-ins/#object
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:21): but then, @codetype didn't make that list either
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:24): I see several <object codetype>s in dotbot data
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:25): and zero <object code>s
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:25): (By "several" I mean about a dozen sites)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:33): http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0A%3Cbody%3E%0A%3Cobject%20id%3Do%3E%3C%2Fobject%3E%3Cscript%3Edocument.getElementById%28%27o%27%29.code%3D1%3C%2Fscript%3E - hmm, browsers support it
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:34): http://google.com/codesearch?q=%3Cobject%5B%5E%3E%5D%2A%5Cscode%3D - some people use it

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:43): Anyone know what sort of feedback MS have been sending on SVG? I heard a bit from ed over lunch, but anyone know what sort of stuff specifically? General technical issues? Stuff you'd find during implementing?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:43): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: thanks. I moved the bug to resolved=invalid
